Buyer beware. I bought my NEW Surface Pro, with the Surface Pen and Surface Type Cover purchased separately on March 11 and received them on March 13. It is now May 17 and so far: 1. I have had to replace the charger. I cleaned the pins, I cleaned the slot. I don't use it around food or drinks. My charged has never fallen on the floor. I tested other people's chargers (they worked!) but mine did not. So on May 11, exactly 2 months to the purchase date, I was spending more money on an already expensive product. 2. The day after the new charger was purchased, the Facial Recognition feature stopped working. As in, that little 'eye' and the red dot near the camera disappeared and I was forced to enter my PIN multiple times a day. This meant that if I had a show or podcast that was streaming and I opened my Surface Pro, there was about a 15 second delay in getting the show to stop blasting at whatever volume I had left it at. Huh, you say? (See #3 below) 3. My Surface Pro would begin playing streaming video and podcasts anytime it was plugged in. So, if I had paused a video on it last night, brought it in to work the next morning, and plugged it in to charge WITHOUT opening it at all, it would start the show at full volume on its own. Who pressed play?!?! Many a day I was left scrambling to hit the pause button on a computer I had not even turned on. Remember, it stopped recognizing my face? So I had to enter the PIN? It would take forever to get to that. Meanwhile, my show would be on full blast. The first time it happened, I plugged in the charger, and rushed away from my desk to a meeting. I returned to some VERY NASTY LOOKS from my colleagues. My video had been running, loudly, for the full 20 minutes I was gone. 4. My Surface Pro would start and stop playing paused videos randomly. Like, at 2AM. Do you know how scary it is to have multiple voices out of nowhere in your bedroom while you are sleeping? My husband and I bolted right up with our hearts racing. Were we being robbed? Was there an emergency? No, it was just my Surface Pro watching videos on its own. 5. The keyboard. *SIGH* Today, the type cover just refused to be recognized. No keys, no touchpad, no backlighting. There are times when merely resting the heel of my palms on the cover (to the sides of the touchpad but below the keys - an area that should have zero functionality or consequence), while typing would cause strange menus and functions to appear onscreen. I'm typing the body of an email and suddenly my text is in the subject line. Of course I don't realize this until a good paragraph in and I can't find the words I'm typing but they have jumped up to the subject line. Or, I'm using the touchpad and in the middle of typing and suddenly 2 other open pages are closed out. 6. Facial Recognition has been restored. Wait, so why am I listing it here as a complaint? Well, that's because I did absolutely nothing to bring it back. So that function seems to come and go at will. Which means I have no control over when it will disappear again. So I have to immediately close every page that has a video after I'm done watching it or take a chance that it'll start playing and facial recognition (the quickest way to turn on my computer) will vanish again and everyone withing earshot will know exactly what i was watching last night. I just bought this computer 2 months ago. Is this what I should expect of a new product?

I won't say that I've used it enough to give a concrete review but it does seem like a good compromise between a laptop and a tablet. One pleasant surprise is that it appears possible to create a wireless connection between it and a projector/display with the purchase of the proper adaptor--I knew I'd need an adaptor but didn't realize there could be a wireless connection. Like a Barbie Doll, it's possible to spend a lot on accessories. Microsoft doesn't (or at least I couldn't find) provide a lot of helpful information for shoppers, so it can be hard to know if you're making good decisions regarding memory, etc. (The closest bricks and mortar store for me is three hours away.) reviews.review_text: I've been looking for a way to ditch the big box PC and go mobile, and after assessing my real use ond needs I realized I didn't need a lot compared to what's available today vs. 20 years ago when my first PC had a 120 MB MFM drive the size of a small car. I usually get the biggest, fastest most feature packed, everything, that I buy. It's the Boy Scout in me I guess, always prepared for the unexpected. However, after realizing I just couldn't ditch Windows OS just yet in lieu of going all the way Andriod, I had to start looking at 2 in 1's etc. I landed on this, the Surface Pro 6. Next was trying to convince myself I needed to change my ways becasue the truth was, I didn't need an i7, 1Tb $2000+ Surface Pro. I actually heeded advice from reviews and benchmarks showing, nothing I do anymore would ever get me to performance of that machine. So next, after looking and discovering that the 2 Tb drive in my big box PC was only at about 250gb capacity with all the years of crap I had on it. Removing the things I really didn't need to have on the machine itself, like a lot of music, and a documents folder that looked like a decades old closet in a hoarders house, I accepted that I could, for the 1st time, accept the minimum spec machine. So I bought the 256gb machine instead because, well you never know,. And, prices dropped! And Black became available at the same dropped price and was in stock. So here I sit typing on the Burgundy Signature Type Cover attached to my new Surface Pro 6 in matte black, with a black Surface Pen firmly attached to the side of the Surface Pro 6 looking as cool as I've ever thought I could never actually look outside of my head! It looks that good! In just a day or so of setting up, adding my apps and programs starting to get used to being so mobile. So far, it's an easier transition that I thought, but I'll still be making a slow move before pulling the plug on the big box. Is it perfect? No, Windows isn't perfect. There's little things like the task-bar will sometimes seem to retreat and not want to come back out with your finger or pen for a short while, but ctrl-Esc pops it right up. Sometimes it seems like when going to Tablet Mode and back, some of the task-bar items don't show back up or are moved around but also easy to fix and so far nothing that's major. Surprisingly the onscreen keyboard(s) aren't as much of an issue as some report. There are options for what keyboard you want and whether you want to keep it on the task-bar etc. and you can pop it u\open and close it for when you need or don't need it, in either PC or tablet mode. Overall, I'm really pleased with my new Surface Pro 6 in matte black, i5, 256gb variant with a Burgundy Signature Type Cover and Black Surface Pen. Going from a desk and big keyboard and a 24" plasma TV as the screen will be a change but so far I can see it being not to bad of a move. I can't always get the Surface Dock and connect it that way if I really need a large screen fix. FYI, for battery life, changing the battery mode makes a big difference. Using max power, makes a few things run smoother and faster as you're expect., like quickly scanning through pictures and videos (like viewing a micro SD card from a game camera quickly skipping past each) but cutting it back to max battery savings also extends it a lot. Some reviews claim battery life isn't near what's advertised, but what's advertised is best scenario and can't account for everyone's usage. I've found the more conservative battery setting is more than enough for most of what I do, with only minor differences when there is a difference. It's a case of YMMV, you're in control of battery life but either way, it's really good! I can't not mention graphics. Wow!! Images are incredible, video, streaming etc. is amazing. It's hard not to want to say it's the best display I've ever experienced.

Overall, great 2in1 device for work and media consumption on the go.

reviews.review_text: Edit after some hardcore use: I took my Surface Pro out to a client manufacturing facility (they make trucks) for a city water survey. I had it in a Moko case. I was absolutely blown away with a few aspects of this device. I was marking up a very large PDF, a layout of the entire building I was in, complete with all city water plumbing drawn. Zooming, panning, marking up, nothing ended up fazing this device performance wise. I used Drawboard PDF, which was exactly fit for my purpose. I was there surveying for 6 hours, no breaks and no charging. I ended up with 63% battery left! Amazing considering the workload(this was a LARGE PDF)! I really cannot say enough good things about this device. I ended up buying the Surface Pen and it is absolutely worth it over the Ciscle. I don't have a single complaint at the moment about this device. I highly recommend it. Original Review:--- I was debating between a new i5 Pro6 and a refurb i5 Pro 5, until I learned that the new i5 in the Pro 6 is a real 4 core 8 thread. I opted for the 6, and oh boy am I glad I did. Performance wise, it really is kind of amazing that a system this powerful can run on passive cooling. I have been mostly using the Surface to annotate PDFs of building blueprints using Drawboard. Zooming, panning, writing, all of it is as fluid as I could ask for, even on massive PDFs of entire factory buildings. Aesthetically, the Surface is a REALLY handsome device. Very pleasing to the eye, and very ergonomic as well. I love folding down into studio mode for drawing. Drawing is great. I opted for a cheap 3rd party pen(Ciscle), but I think I will probably buy a Surface Pen before too long. It is impressive how little lag there is for drawing, it really does feel very natural. I was debating long and hard with myself whether to get the Surface Pro 6, or just get a cheap windows tablet. 300% price difference, but I am absolutely, hands down glad I got the Pro. Awesome device.

To provide context, I bought the Surface Pro 6 to replace my Surface Pro 4 which I traded in at my university's tech store. Display: The display on the Surface Pro 6 is noticeably better than that on the Surface Pro 4 for one reason: contrast ratio. The blacks are blacker and everything is just more vibrant. There is also an sRGB color mode for those of you interested in editing photos or videos. In addition, backlight bleed is virtually nonexistent which was a minor issue on my SP4. The display also gets quite a bit brighter than that of the SP4 which helps significantly in outdoor use. Performance: The performance of the SP6 is noticeably faster than that of the SP4 in day to day tasks, mostly due to doubling the cores and threads (4 & 8 vs 2 & 4). Jumping through powerpoint, excel, word, multiple tabs, and even the notorious CPU hog that is Skype was much snappier. Doing a quick Geekbench, the SP6 is in the performance range of a non-overclocked desktop i5 3570k. SSD performance is also very fast, but it still trails behind what Apple is able to achieve. Battery Life: This is the main reason I wanted to upgrade, as the SP4's battery life was its Achilles heel even when it was new. With my mixed workload of web browsing, MS-office, youtube, Onenote, etc., I would get about 4.5 hours of battery life on the SP4. With the SP6, it's about 8.5 hours. Naturally, your mileage will vary depending on your unique use case, but needless to say, the battery is no longer a weak point of the Surface Pro line. Connectivity: This is honestly the flawed aspect of the SP6. The only ports are a headphone jack (thank you!), a surface connect port, a USB A 3.0 port, and a mini-display port. Not having USB C (preferably thunderbolt 3) on a new device in 2018 is going to be a dealbreaker for some. Personally, the surface acts as my mobile machine with a desktop for work at home, so I almost never need to connect it to a display/peripherals. For those looking to use their surface as a primary machine, it may be a dealbreaker; it depends on your workflow. In terms of Wifi performance, I've had no issues. Keyboard and Pen: I'm using the same keyboard and pen that I used with the SP4, because they are forward compatible. The SP6 keyboard is virtually identical to the SP4 keyboard, so my commentary should still apply. The keys have great spacing and travel, and the trackpad, while small, is smooth and accurate. I can't comment on the latest generation Surface Pen, but for those coming to the SP6 with an older pen in tow, you do still benefit from the improved latency of the SP6 compared to the SP4 and older models. It was a pleasant surprise, and writing on the SP6 feels even more natural as a result. The Little Things: Windows Hello is still awesome and faster than ever. With the instant wake of the SP6, I'm in within 2 seconds of tapping the power button. The build quality is also still exceptional. Overall, the Surface Pro 6 feels like a solid upgrade for users of the Surface Pro 4 and older with significantly better performance and battery life. Being able to use older accessories is on the SP6 is just icing on the cake.

reviews.review_text: For perspective on this review, I've been a Mac user since college, which for me is half a lifetime. My motivation in getting a Surface is pretty simple: I wanted a tablet for my "casual" usage around the house, but I still require full "normal PC" functionality, including the need to put the device into "desktop" mode. I didn't want to have to own two separate devices, and as Apple has made very clear, they are never going to offer a convertible. Even the new iPad-specific iOS version is not going to provide a true PC-like experience, nor the capacity to attach an external display. For those reasons I decided to go ahead and make the switch. Another weird side note: professionally I am a .NET systems architect, so I use Windows at work all day every day, and live in a very Microsoft world. So I'm used to using Windows, yet have never really liked it for my personal use, at home. With all that as background, I really don't have anything but praise for the Surface Pro. I don't quite understand what all the detractors are on about, honestly. It works great -- performance is excellent, as is the design and build quality. It switches very nicely to desktop mode, and works very well as a laptop replacement. The display quality, in particular, is excellent -- better than my 2016-era MacBook Pro. There are a few frustrations, of course: it's Windows OS, so that in and of itself comes along with a list of complaints. But those are all workable, and these days the OS honestly doesn't matter all that much. Windows 10 can be configured to stay pretty-much out of your way, and for me, I never really even notice what OS I'm using, any more. The iteration I purchased is the i5/8GB RAM/256GB SDD. Even as a developer and as someone who dabbles in some higher-performance photo/graphics editing, that model delivers all the performance I need -- even while driving a quad HD external monitor. The device is totally fanless, so there is absolutely no noise at all from it, which is something I really appreciate a lot. I had previously tried to switch to one of Lenovo's convertible tablets, and the fan noise drove me half crazy -- I couldn't do it, and sold the device within a week; went back to my MacBook. This time I do believe the switch is permanent. And as to that, I have to say that I don't know what Apple could possibly be thinking by not offering a convertible tablet. They've lost a lifelong customer in their stubbornness, and I doubt I'm the only one. Microsoft really has a winner on their hands with the Surface Pro. So far I really like it. I'm giving the Surface Pro 4 instead of 5 stars because there is still a lot of room for improvement. As many other reviewers have pointed-out, it's really not acceptable in 2019 to offer a device with a single, standard USB 3.0 port, and no USB C. This doesn't impact me, personally, too much, but it's still a serious drawback, generally, and I get why people are upset by it. There are also some perplexing and truly frustrating oddities in terms of switching between tablet versus desktop mode in Windows 10. For me, I don't even really see the point of having the two modes at all. Overall, though, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend the Surface to just about anyone.

I recently purchased a Surface Pro 6 from Costco and was pleasantly surprised. Microsoft with the Windows monopoly has rarely put out a competitive device in the last decades. The Surface series is the exception, it combines the familiar most commonly used Windows and Apple's ingenious user friendly tablet interface. Complete my work on Word, Excel, Photoshop, detach the keyboard, sit back relax and be entertained on the couch, play games, watch video with a touch of a gesture. It is by no means seamless but close to perfection with each new release. It isn't a dedicated machine to do one job better but many regular jobs we enjoy. Each innovation is getting a step ahead of Apple, my ipad now sits in the closet. We will start with the keyboard, it is magnetically linked, no battery to charge and has a tactile feedback of a full size keyboard. The back stand easily adjust to many angles, making watching movie, typing documents, browsing the net on bed, on the floor, on the couch, on my desk, even sitting on the toilet bowl as comfortable as it can get. No it does not have a USB-C port nor a Firewire port for heavy gamer but there are a ton of accessories you can buy to meet the mass users. Microsoft does not gouge you for money like Apple and the extra microSD port they provided is proof. I added 400Gb of storage with a $78 purchase https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B074RNRM2B/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o03__o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 I interfaced it with my TV with a $7 HDMI adapter https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07GYMM3L5/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05__o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 It is by far the lightest laptop I have ever had for traveling, watched 3 movies downloaded from Netflix before the trip before it ever needs a charge. The screen is super bright, easy to see for my old eyes and the speakers are louder than my 15" gaming laptop. Simply amazing, my impress of Microsoft has changed since.

I purchased the base i5 + 8gb specs (with the upgraded 256gb ssd), and it runs everyday stuff quite well. Absolutely no qualms with the performance. Maybe it's because I came from a 3+ year old laptop, but the screen was absolutely mind blowing when I first started using it. It's obviously a pretty high-res device, but the color is also super on point. I literally admire the screen just browsing normal websites with boring UIs lol. The battery was a bit disappoint at first, but after playing with the brightness/performance mode I was able to get a ton out of it. The 13.5 hour battery claim is probably a pretty significant exaggeration, but it's quite solid with the right settings. Everything about the pro 6 is high performance. The design is super freakin sleek, the black model looks awesome. It really hits the laptop side of the 2in1 concept. However... Windows 10 tablet mode is just so buggy that it really kills tablet use for me. I've owned my surface for 3 days, and tablet mode has already made me want to stop using it as a tablet altogether. More often than not, when I click on a text field (like google search) in chrome, the on-screen keyboard won't pop up, and I'll have to manually click the tiny keyboard button on the taskbar. Having to do this literally hundreds of times through an internet session is much more obnoxious than it sounds. Other tablet-mode bugs: -When trying to use windows 10 search at one point, the onscreen keyboard would only show up as invisible (basically just the border of the keyboard). -Every link I would click would open in a new tab. Took a bit of troubleshooting to realize that microsoft thought the control key was being held down (I definitely hadn't clicked it, and the keyboard was closed, anyway). I had to open up the onscreen keyboard, turn control on, then turn it off to fix it. -When opening up a second window in chrome, windows will randomly spaz out and switch between the two windows rapidly for a good 5-10 seconds. Bizarre. These are the bugs I encountered in just the first 3 days. I can't stress enough how annoying it is for the keyboard to not consistently popup when I click on a textfield in tablet mode. None of these bugs make the device unusable as a tablet, but they make the tablet experience frustrating. Considering the price tag of the pro 6 (plus the type cover, plus the pen), a product the costly shouldn't have such deficiencies. I walked into the store a couple weeks ago and tried every 2-in-1 they had available. I found that Asus and Lenovo had some decent offerings, but I wasn’t truly impressed until I got to the Surface Pro 6. The first thing I noticed was the display. Gorgeous. I knew I had to have it as soon as I held it in portrait mode. I was absolutely sold. After a couple weeks, I’m happy to say that I’ve made the right purchase. I love the versatility and overall functionality of this thing. I can use it as a tablet on my lap, set up the kickstand and watch a movie (on a beautiful 1824p display), or snap on the keyboard and get some work done. The keyboard has a nice clicky feel to it, way better than your average laptop keyboard. The pen is a MUST BUY in my opinion, even if you don’t do much drawing. It’s just part of the Surface experience. Touch screen is super responsive with very little latency and palm rejection works fairly well. I’m really impressed with the performance on my i5 model. I wouldn’t say this thing is a powerhouse by any means (I ran the benchmarks... they were disappointing compared to my desktop build) but the 8th gen quad core i5 is a wonderful thing, and so far I haven’t had any issues with lag or slow performance. Everything has been ultra snappy. In fact, I’m impressed with how much is delivered in such a thin form factor (and fan-less design). I have a Microsoft Surface pro 6 with i7 processor, 16gb ram, 256gb hard drive. I bought this computer hoping to draw, with the newest stylist, and do general writing on Word. I also use it for photo editing using Affinity culling through over 3,000 photos. Overall, I have found the machine difficult to use with the programs I like. (Affinity, Art Rage, Adobe sketchbook, and Word mostly. I also use the photo program that comes with the machine). For drawing I find the Apple Pro outperforms this machine. The combination of the Apple Pro and it's Apple pencil work better, is more accurate, and gives the user a more artistic feel. For working in Affinity Photo, Krita Art or other large art programs, the icons on the programs are so small that I can't see them. Literally, there are so many commands shown on the screen that the print is micro-sized. As I write this review, the print is micro-sized as well. I have not had super small print problems on other laptops. The one game I've tried to play on this machine, is The Operational Art of War 4 from Matrix games. This is a fairly intensive game that uses a lot of computer power, but the makers have figured out how to run it on normal computers with 4 gigs or less RAM and far less speed than my Surface pro 6 has; nonetheless, the game would not play on the Surface Pro. I downloaded it on an older computer with much less RAM and a lesser chip and the game ran fine. I tried loading the game onto the Surface several times, and completely erasing the game each time before the download, but it still fails to run the war game. The keyboard is very good. The pressure on the keys is almost perfect and I have not had the trampoline problems others have reported. The keyboard is thin but works well. One major complaint is the pad in the center of the palm rest. I don't know how it works but it doesn't work anything like the pad on a previous Apple laptop. A very, very light tap seems to trigger the command, and a strong push that causes the pad to click doesn't do anything. Tough for me to figure out. I have attached a normal cheap mouse and that works fine. Using the Surface pen (stylist) doesn't make things any better except when freehand drawing. It does work like your finger on the screen when scrolling, but trying to hit a small command box is harder than using the mouse. In drawing, I feel the stylist is nowhere near as good as the Apple pencil. Overall, the Surface is a disappointment. I bought the fastest, strongest machine I could so runing the photo programs and the art programs would be easy.. However, the programs do not run well on the Surface pro 6, the pen is hard to use for drawing, and the drawing programs have problems the pen does not overcome. Even the Word program is glitchy, in that, I have lost portions of my documents instantly... and without explanation. Out of nowhere I lost two thirds of a long review while I was right in the middle of typing a sentence. No explanationl from Microsoft, and others have complained. This might not be a problem restricted to the Surface, but I've never experienced this difficultly before I started with the Surface and I have not had the problem with any other machine. AD2

If you are an individual who is on the go and always working, Microsoft’s Surface Pro 6 will meet all your needs of being portable and powerful. Why The Surface Worked for Me: My version of the Surface is the i5 processor with 8 GB of Ram and 256 GB of storage. To tech enthusiasts, this would come across as a very low-performance laptop, but in reality, when you’re on the go, this is still excellent performance to portability. For example, after pulling my Surface out from my backpack, it is always ready to work as it boots on in a second. From there, I double click my Surface Pen and my notes are right in front of me. The touchscreen and pen combo then allows me to write my notes as if I’m writing on a piece of paper. Meanwhile, everyone else is still waiting for their bulky laptops to turn on, and I’m ready to face the day. Also, as a Computer Science major, I was surprised at how well the Surface handled big applications in terms of battery life. I usually have several large applications open for entire days ranging from word to excel to even running a server in the background. Despite all the apps running in the background, I am still going through my classes without any hiccups. Even after an overnight stay in the library without a charger, the laptop still has enough power to last me another day. Why it Would Work for You: -You would like a 2-in-1 tablet and laptop combo. -You are always on the go and need to be lightweight. -You want something that is both powerful and can go anywhere with you. -You are often away from an outlet or charger. -You want an intuitive laptop that makes your day easier. -You are a student or often travel. Why it Would Not Work for You: -You rarely see a need for a touch screen. -You have no reason to have a small laptop. -You agree that the price to specs is on the high side, especially for the better models. Final Thoughts: As a student, Microsoft’s Surface Pro 6 met all of my needs. However, the price may be too high and it may not fit all your needs. So, if you feel like you’ve wanted a 2-in-1 laptop that is sleek, powerful, and convenient, then I recommend giving the Surface Pro a shot.

reviews.review_text: I was in the market for a good tablet when I ran across the Surface Pro 6. I liked the fact that it ran Windows 10 and could also function as a laptop and "portable desktop" if needed. As a tablet, I found it glitchy and ill-conceived. The on-screen keyboard functioned inconsistently, and the taskbar was intermittently unresponsive which made it almost impossible to use. I spent hours with Microsoft support trying to get it to work properly, but nothing they did made any difference so I returned it after a week. When reading pdfs, I also found the image quality to be inferior to my desktop and other devices I own; letters were not smooth and had a block-like appearance when zoomed-in. After reading some reviews online, I suspect there may have been nothing wrong with my Surface Pro 6, and the problems I experienced were likely secondary to Windows 10 being a poor tablet OS. In conclusion. the Surface Pro 6 may function well as a laptop or "portable desktop," but it is not a good tablet.
